key_points: The Justice Department has recovered most of the ransom paid to hackers after the Colonial Pipeline cyberattack.
The operation marks the first of its kind by a ransomware task force created by the Biden administration.
Deputy Attorney General Lisa Monaco highlighted the effort to increase the cost and consequences of ransomware attacks.
The attack led Colonial Pipeline, a major fuel supplier, to halt operations on May 7.
Colonial Pipeline paid a ransom of 75 bitcoin, valued at approximately $4.4 million, to the hackers to resume operations.
FBI was able to identify and seize 63.7 bitcoins, now valued at $2.3 million, from the hackers.
The seizure amounted to 85% of the total ransom paid.
The operation aimed to disrupt ransomware operations and hold hackers accountable according to Colonial Pipeline's CEO, Joseph Blount.
Ransomware attacks have been increasing, targeting critical industries globally.
The FBI discourages ransom payments but suggests that quick law enforcement engagement can sometimes help recover funds.
spokespersons: Joseph Blount (President and Chief Executive, Colonial Pipeline)
Stephanie Hinds (Acting U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of California)
